@vchuravy i Just created a [branch](https://github.com/Godricly/mxnet/tree/BN-DType/src/operator) so u can start from here. There are some parameters typed float in previous BN. Should we convert them into DType? I left comments started with "Issue: " so u can jump there by find.

Here is the problem:
GTX 1080 + CUDA 8.0 = mxnet returns zeros for mx.nd.ones()
GTX 1080 + CUDA 7.5 = curand() doesn't work (NVIDIA issue) and mxnet relies on curand for some tasks. But training on CPU works
So you either need to remove all references to curand (e.g. initialize your arrays manually), or switch back to an older card.
run   python train_cifar10.py --batch-size 128 --lr 0.1 --lr-factor .94 --num-epoch 50 --save-model-prefix "cifar10_model"   to save your model first

actually, The fc layer does not support FP16 on cpu side.
[code link](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/fully_connected.cc#L19)
working on following fc layer to pass compiling as temporary fix. (compilation passed)

Hi, thanks again! But now backing to MLP, we set up a 3-layer MLP for our task. However, the results are very low, accuracy is around 10.0%, compared with SVM's, 90.0%. We'r not sure if we made some mistakes (overfitting?), because when training in MATLAB with a sam 3-layer MLP, it can achieve around 70.0%. How do you suggest to do with MXNet settings if we wanna a better results?

First thing is to check if your data iter giving correct data format as you implemented by urself. Second is to check the MLP setup. Then plot the training and validation curve given the same setup u had in Matlab, I hope u can get sth in this step by comparing them. The worst situation is to debug each layer one by one, I hope you don't have to do this. If you come to this last situation, pycharm is a good choice according to my experience.
@Godricly you nearly had everything, the primary thing that was missing is that all constant need to be `tcast<DType>(scalar(...))` or `scalar<DType>(value)` in expressions.

For ndarray actually yes unless you do nd.expand_dims(x, out=x, axis=1). For symbolic operator, usually inplace will happen and no operations will be taken

I would need to mention one thing. Simply support half_t type was not enough for making things faster with fp16. Usually a explicit vectorization of code is needed. So unless things are operated together in a Packet structure with intrinsics. There is less likely to be speedup.
It would be better if we can allocate tmp space in executor mem pool

LGTM.

BTW, don't forget the mid-term evaluation.
module is a newer interface. we recommend module for new projects.
You can use the pre-built GPU lib by @hjk41 and follow https://github.com/Lodewic/mxnet/blob/f127a693500f834209aef607ebd21e591334277e/doc/build.md#r-package-installation

@tqchen @piiswrong So right now we have to wrap all parameters to be of `DType`. The general solution (which I am looking into right now) is to enable mshadow expressions with mixed DTypes (primarily scalars of type `real_t` and tensors of `DType`).
Current interface do not yet allow doing so. However, the temp space is usually already shared across each of operators via sharing the same resource
@winstywang @piiswrong

@LeagueOfCodes  I looked at this again. There are two possible cause of the difference
- MXNet has more synchronization overhead between each ops. This should be fixed by #2496 
- The different choice of CUDNN algorithms. Since from the prof, the algorithm choice was quite different between the two, it could because somehow the selection algorithm choose a bad algorithm in this case.

It is likely that you can confirm which is the case by see how #2496 works, and we can proceed to fix the remaining problem
Thank you for you reminder. I have completed the mid-term evaluation right now. :)
me too

Also of recent interest: Baidu just released this: https://github.com/baidu-research/persistent-rnn
The interface is modelled after cuDNN.
it was compiling issue with those mshadow_op on cpu side using half_t. But now In batchnorm.cc, the half_t is disable for cpu like it is in fc layer. So it passed.
How about to add a reshape layer at the end of your network?
@javelinjs Seems like there's conflict and seg fault in cpp test.

It sounds like the underlining mshadow needs optimization for data alignment. Another thing I'm thinking about is whether we should add a option to enable backward computation in higher precision(float) for half_t type. The half_t type cannot represent too small gradients. And it will be messy in coding to enable this.  
Working on embedding now.

There are several issues to be solved:
1. The code is a llittle outdated. 
2. it is only available using cudnn on gpu.
3. Is 3d conv supported alone or merged into current conv framework?
4. cudnnv5 Issue
        cudnnSetFilterNdDescriptor function requires a format input only considered 4D case. It still works for me when I use NCHW format, but I'm still worried about it. I wrote an email to nvidia but no answer yet.

link: [mxnet supporting 3d](https://github.com/Liquidburner/mxnet/tree/master/src/operator)

I had a same problem, expect to solve.

Some points for CPU inference in Caffe that might be useful:
- For tiny models, there are a few unnecessary allocations in the forward pass in a few layers during reshaping. Only reshaping when shapes change helps a bit.
- Inlining execution (when you can guarantee that all dependencies of a child operator have concluded whe executing a parent, running the child directly instead of throwing back into a job queue) helps a lot for some networks.
- Specifically for convolutional networks on Haswell or above Intel CPUs at reasonable batch sizes (>32 or so), using NNPACK helps a lot (see https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/issues/4264 for an example integration). I'd suggest wrapping that in MXNet as a plugin, it's a really useful library in some scenarios.

Thanks @ajtulloch  the inlining execution is added in #2496 

The NNPack could be an interesting thing to add

Tuning OMP_NUM_THREADS and OPENBLAS_NUM_THREADS can make much difference.
According to our experiments, setting OMP_NUM_THREADS to the number of
cores of a single CPU performs best in a multi-socket machine. The
difference can be more than 2X.

NNPACK seems interesting. Intel has been working on similar things in MKL.
It is said that a DNN-optimized MKL version will be released at Q4 this
year.
